titleproper.value:
Guide to the Class of 1892 Scrapbook
                    <num>MC 240</num>

author.value: Finding aid prepared by Celeste Brewer.

creation.value:
This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit
                <date>2015-06-23T16:22-0400</date>

abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value: The Class of 1892 Scrapbook is a single bound volume containing photographs and Commencement ephemera of the University of the City of New York (now New York University) Class of 1892. Contemporaneous photographs of university faculty members are also present. The Class of 1892 attended the University of the City of New York during a period of transition in the university’s history. They were among the last to experience the undergraduate college at Washington Square, before the move to the University Heights campus and demolition of the old University Building in 1894.

p.value: The scrapbook is open for use without restrictions. However, the fragility of the binding and age of the materials require very careful handling.
Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, 1892; Class of 1892 Scrapbook; MC 240; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

3. New York University. 
                <emph render="italic">General Alumni Catalogue of New York University</emph>. New York: General Alumni Society of New York University, 1916.

The volume appears to have been maintained by the class statistician, Arthur C. Perry, after graduation. On the inside of the front cover, Perry noted the names and fraternity affiliations of the class members, including those not pictured in the volume. He also noted which members of the class were deceased, suggesting that he kept in touch with his classmates after graduation. The early classes of the University of the City of New York had a tradition of holding yearly formal meetings, beginning during the members’ freshman year and continuing until all but one member of the class had passed away.

corpname.value: University of the City of New York.
